Q: I am fully vaccinated and just traveled to an area with low vaccination rates, does that mean I have to get tested for COVID?
A: Even if you’re fully vaccinated, you should still wear a mask during your trip and get tested after visiting an area with low vaccination rates.

Q: Do I need to wear a mask?
A: If you’re not vaccinated, the CDC recommends that you always wear a mask. If you’re fully vaccinated, the CDC recommends wearing masks indoors in COVID hotspots.

Q: Will my vaccine (J&J, Moderna, or Pfizer) protect against the delta variant?
A: All vaccines have shown protections against symptomatic diseases and hospitalizations against the delta variant. If you’re not vaccinated, the delta variant can potentially be life-threatening.

Refunds by direct deposit will begin July 28 and refunds by paper check will begin July 30. This is the fourth round of refunds related to the unemployment compensation exclusion provision.

The American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, which became law in March, excluded up to $10,200 in 2020 unemployment compensation from taxable income calculations. The exclusion applied to individuals and married couples whose modified adjusted gross income was less than $150,000.

The IRS reported today that another 1.5 million taxpayers will receive refunds averaging more than $1,600 as it continues to adjust unemployment compensation from previously filed income tax returns.

Student debt cancellation is good policy, good politics, and something that @POTUS has the power to do with the stroke of his pen. We need him to use it.

Asking “how we’re going to pay for it” misses the point. 

We should be asking how we’re going to pay for the status quo. 

We need to look at student loan cancellation as an investment, one that will pay dividends that benefit us all - including people who didn’t attend college.

Student debt cancellation is also the single most effective way to reduce the racial wealth gap. Black and brown borrowers are forced to borrow more, at higher rates, than their white counterparts.

Cancelling student loan debt would close the Black-White wealth gap by 28 points.
By freeing people from the burden of student debt, we enable them to start families, buy homes, launch small businesses, and fully engage in our economy.

Cancelling student debt isn’t just the right thing to do -- it’s the smart thing to do. 

According to leading economists, cancelling student debt would create over 1 million jobs per year.

In fact, President Biden has already used this authority.

Just last month, he cancelled more than $500 million in student debt held by nearly 18,000 students defrauded by ITT Tech.

What’s more, regulations issued by the Justice and Treasury Departments give the Secretary the clear authority “to compromise a debt, or suspend or terminate collection of a debt,” arising from a Title IV loan program. 

Title IV loans make up over 90% of student loan debt.

The Higher Education Act gives the Secretary of Education the power to “enforce, pay, compromise, waive, or release any right, title, claim, lien, or demand, however acquired.”

In other words, it gives him the power to cancel any student debt held by the federal government.

There’s been a lot of factually inaccurate talk about student debt cancellation today, so let’s clear a few things up.

President Biden has the clear authority to liberate 43 million Americans from the crushing burden of student debt. He needs to use it.
